questions.explanation: Cargo needs to be secured appropriately to prevent it from moving in transit. Cargo should be arranged to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low and well-distributed.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerB: Not touch the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.answerB: Glued down.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers or trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to keep it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: Without oil in its engine:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will likely run smoothly.
questions.answerB: A vehicle will make quick jerks while driving.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's engine may be damaged quickly.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's gas mileage will improve.
questions.explanation: An engine can be rapidly destroyed if it is run without oil. If its oil pressure gauge is low or fluctuating, do not operate a vehicle.

questions.question: When switching gears, what happens if you remain in neutral for too long?
questions.answerB: You may have trouble getting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.answerD: The vehicle will be difficult to stop.
questions.explanation: Remaining in neutral for too long when shifting gears may make it difficult to put the vehicle into the next gear.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a problem?
questions.answerB: Loose or broken mounting brackets
questions.answerC: Exhaust parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not leaking
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: During the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: A pull-up always counts against the applicant.
questions.answerB: A pull-up should be completed at least once.
questions.answerC: Stopping without changing direction is not considered a pull-up.
questions.answerD: Excessive pull-ups are acceptable in the opinions of some test administrators.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, a pull-up will be scored any time an applicant stops and pulls forward to gain a better position. Stopping without changing direction will not. An excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerB: Daydreaming
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: The best way to avoid glare at night from oncoming vehicles is to:
questions.answerB: Close your eyes as vehicles approach.
questions.answerC: Look to the right side of road.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded by the lights of oncoming vehicles, you can glance to the right side of the road until the vehicle has passed.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.answerB: Mechanical
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of the way of other drivers.
questions.answerB: Try not to use your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a large CMV is always dangerous because you will not be able to see everything behind you. If you must back up, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: How can you prevent drowsiness before a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about four hours of sleep.
questions.answerB: Plan stopping points into your trip in advance.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on a long trip, strategies include getting adequate sleep beforehand; planning out the route and stopping points in advance; driving with a passenger; and driving at times during which you are normally awake.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time, emphasizing different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time so you are less likely to forget something.
questions.answerD: By someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to reduce driving distractions?
questions.answerB: Planning the route before driving
questions.explanation: Strategies for avoiding distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Hydraulic brakes can fail for one of two reasons. Which of the following is one of those reasons?
questions.answerA: There is a loss of hydraulic pressure.
questions.answerB: You are driving uphill.
questions.answerD: The brakes are used too much in one day.
questions.explanation: Most hydraulic brake failures occur for one of two reasons. A first likely cause of brake failure is that the brakes have been overused on a downgrade, causing them to fade. The second likely cause is that there has been a loss of hydraulic pressure in the braking system. Brakes kept in good condition will rarely fail, but you should know which steps to take in case they do.

questions.question: When driving down a steep grade, your brakes may fade. What happens if brakes fade?
questions.answerB: They become less effective.
questions.answerD: They work differently from front to back.
questions.explanation: If you use your brakes too much when traveling on a steep downgrade, they may overheat and become less effective. To avoid causing your brakes to overheat on a steep hill, you should rely on engine braking.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly, before other vehicles can enter into the lane.
questions.answerB: Move slowly in case another vehicle is in the lane.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If there is a vehicle in the other lane that you did not see before beginning to move, they will have more time to react to your vehicle.

questions.question: To make it as safe as possible to leave a stop, you should park:
questions.answerA: So that you must back up to leave your parking space.
questions.answerB: So that you can pull forward to leave your parking space.
questions.answerC: On the side of a roadway, not in a parking lot.
questions.answerD: By backing into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Backing can be dangerous, so avoid doing it whenever you can. If possible, park in such a way that allows you to pull forward to exit your parking space.

questions.question: When a construction worker is close to the road, you should:
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerD: Wait until the construction is complete before proceeding.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should drive at the posted speed limits. Reduce your speed even further when workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: Be sure you are always driving so your vehicle can stop:
questions.answerA: Within 10 feet of your current position.
questions.answerB: Within 1,000 feet of your current position.
questions.answerC: Within your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be sure that you are driving in a manner that will allow your vehicle to come to a complete stop, if necessary, within the area of the road ahead that you are able to see.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: During a written exam:
questions.answerA: Cell phones may be placed on airplane mode.
questions.answerB: Cell phones must be turned off.
questions.answerC: Cell phones may be left on, but must be set in a face down position.
questions.answerD: Cell phones may be left on.
questions.explanation: All electronic devices must be turned off while a written exam is being taken.

questions.question: If a person operates in both excepted and non-excepted intrastate commerce, which type of license should the driver select?
questions.answerB: Excepted
questions.explanation: To operate in both excepted intrastate commerce and non-excepted intrastate commerce, you must choose a non-excepted intrastate commerce license.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: When you need to brake, how can you warn drivers behind you?
questions.answerA: Tap on the brakes a couple of times.
questions.answerB: Stick your arm out the window.
questions.explanation: To warn drivers behind you that you are about to slow down, it may be a good idea to first lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to make the brake lights flash.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Dual
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: When performing the stop/start maneuver as a part of the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Cut off other vehicles if needed to get onto the shoulder.
questions.answerB: Not use any turn signals.
questions.answerC: Slam on the brakes to stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be asked to pull your vehicle over to the side of the road and stop as if you were going to get out and check something on your vehicle. As you prepare to make this stop, you must check traffic; activate your turn signal; decelerate smoothly with even braking, changing gears as needed; and bring your vehicle to a full stop without coasting.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Obey all traffic laws.
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.answerB: Six fuses
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: In a school bus, where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door on the passenger side of the bus
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. Its purpose is to allow the driver to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: A school bus must be evacuated if:
questions.answerA: The bus has stalled in winter weather conditions.
questions.answerB: The air conditioning system has broken.
questions.answerC: There is any imminent danger of collision.
questions.explanation: During emergency situations, it is usually safest for students to remain on a school bus. Evacuations are mandatory if the bus has stalled on railroad tracks, if the bus is on fire or there is a threat of fire, or if there is a hazardous materials spill. Students should be evacuated any time there is imminent danger of collision.

questions.question: When checking the springs during a vehicle inspection, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Look for broken coil springs.
questions.answerC: Ensure torsion springs are not damaged.
questions.explanation: When checking the springs as part of the vehicle inspection test, you should look for missing, shifted, cracked, or broken leaf springs, as well as broken or distorted coil springs. If the vehicle is equipped with torsion bars, torque arms, or other types of suspension components, ensure that they are not damaged and are mounted securely.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: When unloading students at a school, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the ignition switch.
questions.answerB: Keep the key in the ignition and leave the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When dropping children off at a school, the bus driver should secure the bus by turning off the ignition. The driver should remove the key if they leave the driver's compartment.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Failing to exit your vehicle properly during an exercise in the basic vehicle control skills test will result in:
questions.answerB: A reset of that exercise.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.answerD: An extra point against your score.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.answerB: 100 feet
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Obey all traffic signs.
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerB: Fully raised.
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerB: Strongly discouraged.
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.answerD: Only to be done with students guiding you.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other way to move the vehicle.

questions.question: When you are approaching a bus stop, the students on your bus should:
questions.answerB: Stand up and collect their belongings.
questions.answerC: Walk to the front of the bus and prepare to exit.
questions.explanation: Students on a school bus should remain seated until they are told otherwise. It is unsafe for students to walk around the bus while it is moving.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.answerB: Above the outside flat mirrors.
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.answerB: Always use the windows.
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.answerB: Two times
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: Failing to exit your vehicle properly during an exercise in the basic vehicle control skills test will result in:
questions.answerB: A reset of that exercise.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.answerD: An extra point against your score.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror:
questions.answerA: Allows the driver to see what is happening inside of the bus.
questions.answerB: Allows the driver to see what is happening outside of the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: Outside mirrors on a school bus should be adjusted:
questions.answerB: During a trip.
questions.explanation: All mirrors on a school bus should be checked and adjusted before beginning a trip. Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safety of all students and surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerB: Leave the item behind.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: If a student drops an item while approaching the bus, the student should:
questions.answerA: Stop and pick up the object.
questions.answerB: Have another student pick up the object.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Just leave the item alone and walk away.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: Before leaving a bus stop, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make sure no students are running to catch the bus.
questions.answerB: Make sure students have placed their backpacks in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Make sure students have opened the emergency vent.
questions.answerD: Make sure students are facing the rear of the bus.
questions.explanation: Before pulling away from a bus stop, a driver should make sure that there are no students running to catch the bus.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerD: Can be done with the driver talking to another driver.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading. The process must be properly supervised and done with care.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: Points are deducted for each pull-up.
questions.answerB: A driver is allowed three pull-ups per maneuver.
questions.answerC: A pull-up will earn points only if the driver gets out of the vehicle before pulling up.
questions.answerD: Only an excessive number of pull-ups will be counted as errors.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, there is no penalty for an initial pull-up; however, an excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a backing maneuver that you will be asked to perform during the basic control skills test?
questions.answerB: Offset back/right
questions.explanation: Backing maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right, offset back/left, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerB: The lift is not leaking.
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.answerB: Drive less carefully.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps stop wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. With ABS on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same way that you would without ABS on your vehicle.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerB: Do not have control devices.
questions.answerD: Usually have a flagger directing traffic.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume you'll hear an approaching train.
questions.answerB: Rely solely on signals to tell you if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Open the door and listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Immediately proceed after a train has passed.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: When inspecting engine compartment belts during the vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: The belts should be checked for snugness, each with up to three inches of play.
questions.answerB: The water pump belt does not need to be identified.
questions.answerC: The air compressor belt should be removed.
questions.answerD: The applicant must identify which items are not belt-driven, if any.
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you must check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts. In addition to cracks and frays, you should check the belts for snugness, allowing up to three-quarters of an inch of play at the center of each belt. If any of these items are not belt-driven, you must identify them and ensure that their components are operating properly, are not damaged or leaking, and are mounted securely.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Obey all traffic signs.
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerB: Strongly discouraged.
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.answerD: Only to be done with students guiding you.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should be done only if there is no other way to move the vehicle.

questions.question: During the skills test, if making a turn that requires a stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop after the stop line to get a better view.
questions.answerD: Keep the front wheels aimed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must come to a stop before making a turn during the driving skills test, you should come to a smooth stop behind any stop line, crosswalk, or stop sign. Keep your front wheels aimed straight ahead and do not let your vehicle roll. If stopping behind another vehicle, stop where you are still able to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead of you.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerD: A maximum of four feet tall.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials must be braced so that they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.answerB: Where materials originate.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle that contains hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: No other vehicles should be at the refueling station.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: What shape is a placard indicating hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: Triangle
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine.
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.answerB: The carrier
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerB: With electric lights.
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Four
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: How must a shipper notify a driver of the risks associated with their cargo?
questions.answerB: By writing a note on a blank piece of paper
questions.answerC: By putting hazard warning labels on packages
questions.answerD: By placing orange dots on packages
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous cargo must alert drivers and others to relevant hazards through proper shipping papers, hazard warning labels on packages, emergency response information, and placards.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tire.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package, a ____ placard must be used.
questions.answerB: Explosive
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on a package or its shipping paper, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate, must be displayed.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerB: Eyeballing the tires.
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerB: A return address.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: What could indicate that a shipment you are accepting contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: What must be included in emergency response information?
questions.answerB: Value of the materials
questions.explanation: The emergency response information for a cargo of hazardous materials must include details about risks of fire or explosion associated with the materials.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.answerB: Class 3
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: How do you label a hazardous material if the proper label will not fit on the material's package?
questions.answerA: The label may be placed on a tag securely attached to the package.
questions.answerB: A scannable QR code may instead be attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The HazMat label should be reduced in size to fit on the package.
questions.answerD: The label may be pasted to the wall of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit on a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerA: Should only be used with explosives.
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should only be used by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.answerD: Should be used to reduce insurance rates.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards must be used on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: When placing a placard:
questions.answerA: It should be at least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: It could be placed under a ladder if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: It can be affixed to a background of similar color.
questions.explanation: Among other requirements, hazardous materials placards must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings; away from ladders or other attachments or devices; on backgrounds of contrasting color; and upright, with words or numbers level and reading left to right.

questions.question: Regulations require hazardous materials employees to be trained and tested how often?
questions.answerB: Once every three years
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years. Drivers must learn the risks associated with hazardous materials and be able to properly respond to security threats.

questions.question: Containers of nitric acid should be:
questions.answerA: Stacked no more than two containers high.
questions.answerB: Stacked to the ceiling.
questions.answerC: Loaded on top of other products.
questions.explanation: Nitric acid should not be stacked above any other product. Containers of nitric acid may be stacked, but no higher than two containers high.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Those around you.
questions.explanation: Due to the risks involved, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials. These regulations exist to protect the driver, others near the vehicle, and the environment.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.answerB: 25 feet
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.answerB: An air conditioner.
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You can proceed without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: You can proceed without stopping if no other vehicles are within sight.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track.

questions.question: Shipping papers identifying hazardous materials should be:
questions.answerA: At the bottom of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerB: On the top of a stack of shipping papers.
questions.answerC: In a location separate from non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Carriers and drivers must be able to quickly identify hazardous materials' shipping papers. Shipping papers for hazardous materials should be on the top of a stack of shipping papers.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.answerB: Where materials originate.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.answerB: Federal Bureau of Investigation
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a background check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: To know which placards to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which hazardous materials placards to use, you must know the hazard class of the materials; the amount of hazardous materials being shipped; and the total weight of all classes of hazardous materials in the vehicle.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.answerB: Away from heat sources.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerB: Made from an iron alloy.
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: What must be included in emergency response information?
questions.answerB: Value of the materials
questions.explanation: The emergency response information for a cargo of hazardous materials must include details about risks of fire or explosion associated with the materials.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle can only be moved:
questions.answerA: To make room for other vehicles.
questions.answerB: During an emergency.
questions.answerC: If the vehicle will be traveling a distance shorter than 10 miles.
questions.explanation: A vehicle must be properly placarded before it can be driven. A vehicle that does not display the proper placards may not be moved unless doing so is necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The packages should be carried in the cab.
questions.answerC: The packages should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation surrounds packages of radioactive materials and passes through to other nearby packages. To address this, the number of radioactive packages that can be loaded together is limited.

questions.question: A driver must take the HazMat knowledge test:
questions.answerB: Prior to every CDL renewal.
questions.explanation: You must take and pass the written English version of the HazMat knowledge test and be cleared through a federal background check before every renewal of your CDL.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table contains:
questions.answerB: Where the materials originated.
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Two
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of materials being shipped?
questions.answerB: The carrier
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for identifying the product's identification number; proper shipping name; hazard class; packing group; and correct packaging, labels, marking, and placards.

questions.question: To determine which placard(s) you must use when carrying hazardous materials, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers being used.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards are placed on the outside of a vehicle to identify the hazard classes of materials being carried.

questions.question: On packages that are not large enough to hold a HazMat label, materials should be labeled:
questions.answerB: With a tag.
questions.answerC: With a piece of orange tape.
questions.explanation: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to display the proper label, the label may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.answerB: An approved gas mask
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect:
questions.answerB: Those around you.
questions.explanation: Transporting hazardous materials can be risky. The regulations are intended to protect you, those around you, and the environment.

questions.question: When accepting a package of hazardous materials, a driver should ensure:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: That all packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: When carrying hazardous materials, it is a good idea to compare the shipping papers to the markings and labels on the packages.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Gases.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: If hazardous materials are being transported, how are other drivers warned?
questions.answerA: By the posting of placards on the truck
questions.answerB: By the flashing lights on the truck
questions.answerD: By the driver waving an arm out the window
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials to alert other drivers to the presence of the materials.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: At least how many placards must be placed on a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is required to have hazardous materials placards, at least four identical placards must be displayed. These placards must be placed on the front, back, and both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.answerD: The shipping paper is not in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to compare a shipping paper to the applicable package markings and labels. Ensure that the shipper has included the correct basic description on the shipping paper and that it matches markings and labels.

questions.question: What could indicate that a shipment you are accepting contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, what letters will appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.answerB: LT
questions.explanation: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerB: Are waived on the weekends.
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.answerB: Chock the wheels.
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerB: Open the hood.
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: When stopped on the side of the road, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn on their emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, it is important to turn on your four-way emergency flashers to warn other road users.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection is required:
questions.answerB: To get fuel.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require that CMV drivers inspect their vehicles before every trip.

questions.question: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerB: Separate from the axle.
questions.answerC: Push against the inside of the drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: Coupling can be tested by a driver:
questions.answerA: Placing their fingers inside the coupling mechanism.
questions.answerB: Pulling against the pin of the second semi-trailer.
questions.answerC: Placing glue over the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Releasing the orange lever in the cab.
questions.explanation: It is essential to safety that a driver inspects coupling before starting a trip. Trailer coupling on a double or triple combination can be tested by pulling against the pin of the second semi-trailer.

questions.question: Joggers who are wearing headsets:
questions.answerA: Are usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can clearly hear sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may not be able to clearly hear surrounding traffic and may not be aware that you are there.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a truck's cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: After a trip:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should be placed out-of-service.
questions.answerB: A vehicle's oil should be changed.
questions.answerC: A vehicle's after-trip inspection should be completed.
questions.answerD: A vehicle's battery should be disconnected.
questions.explanation: After a trip, you may be required to perform an inspection and file a report on each vehicle that you've driven.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: Regarding winter driving, all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: Front tires should have a tread depth of at least 4/32 an inch.
questions.answerB: Tires should be slightly deflated.
questions.answerC: Rear tires should have a tread depth of at least 2/32 an inch.
questions.answerD: Use a gauge to verify that each tire has a safe tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is particularly important that your tires have adequate tread. You need a tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch on the back tires. Check the tread depths by using a gauge.

questions.question: Doubles and triples are:
questions.answerB: Most likely to turn over due to the "crack-the-whip" effect.
questions.answerC: Easier to drive than other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Less likely to be affected by wind than other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Double and triple trailer combinations are more likely to turn over due to the "crack-the-whip" effect than are other combination vehicles. Drivers must steer gently when pulling trailers.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: If the brakes “pull” to one side or the other when you use them, it's a sign that:
questions.answerB: The brakes need to be checked.
questions.answerD: The brakes have too much stopping power.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle "pulls" to one side when braking, you may have brake trouble. If there is an issue with your brakes, you should fix the issue before driving. Operating an unsafe vehicle is against federal and state laws.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: Which of the following is required emergency equipment?
questions.answerB: A flashlight
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What happens if the air pressure in a system's air tanks falls below 60 psi?
questions.answerA: A warning light will come on.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will not shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low pressure warning signal should activate if the pressure in the air tanks falls to a level below 60 psi. This signal may be in the form of a warning light or a wig wag.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerB: The right lane
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: A danger of a large truck swerving to avoid a hazard is:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerB: The truck may flip over.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.answerD: Other vehicles may do the same thing.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop. However, swerving while in a vehicle that is either top-heavy or pulling multiple trailers may result in a rollover.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Notifying the proper authorities.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: When inspecting a double or triple trailer that has more parts than a smaller tractor-trailer combination:
questions.answerA: To save time, not all parts need to be inspected.
questions.answerB: A driver should only inspect the first trailer and its parts.
questions.answerC: A driver should only inspect the rear trailer and its parts.
questions.answerD: A driver should inspect all parts to ensure safety.
questions.explanation: Doubles and triples should be inspected using the same process that is used to inspect other vehicles. A driver should expect a properly thorough inspection of a double or triple to take more time than an inspection of a smaller vehicle.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.answerB: Motorcycles
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.answerB: A three-axle tractor
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerB: Requires more driving skill
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, how can you tell if the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working?
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the rear of the trailer will stay on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the trailer will flash three times and then stay on.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights on the trailer will flash and then shut off.
questions.answerD: The blue light near the driver's door will light.
questions.explanation: Trailers equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are equipped on the left rear with a yellow malfunction lamp. If the malfunction lamp stays on after the engine has been started, the ABS is malfunctioning.

questions.question: How can you prevent drowsiness before a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about four hours of sleep.
questions.answerB: Plan stopping points into your trip in advance.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on a long trip, strategies include getting adequate sleep beforehand; planning out the route and stopping points in advance; driving with a passenger; and driving at times during which you are normally awake.

questions.question: If a roadway is covered by fog, it is best for you to:
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous. If possible, you should always avoid driving under foggy conditions.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.answerB: The utility line
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line may also be referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: When inspecting coupling equipment before a trip, the fifth wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Loosely mounted.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the convertor dolly, make sure all components are present and in proper working condition. Be sure to check the upper and lower fifth wheel, the air lines, and the electric lines. The fifth wheel should be properly greased and securely mounted.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to remove the vehicle from the tracks.
questions.answerD: Walk down the tracks to look for an oncoming train.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be held:
questions.answerB: With one hand, keeping the other hand free for other tasks.
questions.answerC: With one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: At the base of the wheel.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: React to the driver's gestures.
questions.answerC: Challenge the driver to a road race.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly, before other vehicles can enter into the lane.
questions.answerB: Move slowly in case another vehicle is in the lane.
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If there is a vehicle in the other lane that you did not see before beginning to move, they will have more time to react to your vehicle.

questions.question: What is a danger of rolling back when you start to accelerate?
questions.answerB: The truck is not made to go backwards.
questions.answerC: You may hit a vehicle behind you.
questions.answerD: You may lose your position in traffic.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting someone or something behind you, it is important to ensure that your vehicle does not roll backwards when starting from a stop. If your vehicle has a manual transmission, partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Expect to hear a train.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks before an approaching train reaches the crossing.
questions.explanation: You should approach every railroad crossing with the expectation that a train is coming. Do not rely on signals or your hearing to reliably tell you if a train is present. Always slow down when approaching a crossing. Never try to race a train.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: Leaking shock absorbers:
questions.answerB: Indicate a potentially dangerous defect.
questions.answerC: Will prevent the turn signals from working.
questions.answerD: Pose no threat if the vehicle is only driven on highways.
questions.explanation: The suspension system keeps a vehicle's axles in place. Damaged suspension parts, such as leaking shock absorbers, may be potentially dangerous defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerB: A trailer to straighten out.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: To drive safely, it is important to remember:
questions.answerA: How much distance your vehicle needs to stop.
questions.answerB: Possible shortcuts along your planned route.
questions.answerC: That arriving to your destination on time is the most important thing.
questions.answerD: That other drivers will move out of your way when you are merging with traffic.
questions.explanation: To drive safely, it is important to remember how much distance your vehicle will need to stop. Stopping distance for a vehicle can change with road conditions, weather conditions, and the quality of cargo in the vehicle's tanks.

questions.question: What is a concern immediately after it begins raining?
questions.answerA: The water will mix with grease and oil on the road, making the roadway slippery.
questions.answerB: A driver may forget where the windshield wiper lever is located.
questions.answerD: People will be using their windshield wipers needlessly.
questions.explanation: Under wet conditions, roads are often most slippery when it first begins to rain. This is because the water mixes with oil and grease on the road that has not yet begun to wash away.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.answerB: Made from an iron alloy.
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
